title: The Moves Against the Census
description: A reader says the government’s actions obscure accuracy and harm the country. Also: Voting is a necessity.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: A New York police union endorses Trump.
description: A union representing tens of thousands of New York City police officers endorsed President Trump for re-election on Friday, citing what leaders said was Mr. Trump’s defense of the authorities and concern for public safety at a time they said their members have been “under attack.”
content: A union representing tens of thousands of New York City police officers endorsed President Trump for re-election on Friday, citing what leaders said was Mr. Trump’s defense of the authorities and concern for public safety at a time they said their members have been “under attack.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: New York Has a 14-Day Quarantine. Many New Yorkers Are Ignoring It.
description: Travelers returning from states with high infection rates say they are following the rules, but their social media posts say otherwise.
content: Earlier this summer, Sasha Pagan burst into tears during her nursing shift at a hospital on Manhattan’s Upper East Side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1,300,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Caldwell
title: Henrik Lundqvist, Key to Rangers’ Past Glory, Awaits His Future
description: The 38-year-old goalie will soon be entering the final year of his contract with the team.
content: Henrik Lundqvist had no guarantee he would play for the Rangers when the N.H.L. postseason started this month after a four-month layoff because of the coronavirus pandemic. But at 38, he is still a goaltender with goals, and foremost among them was savoring any chance to play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Catie Edmondson
title: Pelosi to Recall House for Postal Service Vote as Democrats Press for DeJoy to Testify
description: The House will cut short its summer recess to consider legislation that would counter changes at the Postal Service that critics say undermine casting ballots by mail.
content: WASHINGTON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California announced on Sunday that she would call the House back from its annual summer recess for a vote this week on legislation to block changes at the Postal Service that voting advocates warn could disenfranchise Americans casting ballots by mail during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 16, 2020
description: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, Aug. 16, 2020.
content: An article last Sunday about the author H. P. Lovecraft’s legacy misidentified the setting of the film “Re-Animator.” It is the fictional town of Arkham, Mass., in the 1980s, not contemporary Chicago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Fearing a ‘Twindemic,’ Health Experts Push Urgently for Flu Shots
description: There’s no vaccine for Covid-19, but there’s one for influenza. With the season’s first doses now shipping, officials are struggling over how to get people to take it.
content: As public health officials look to fall and winter, the specter of a new surge of Covid-19 gives them chills. But there is a scenario they dread even more: a severe flu season, resulting in a “twindemic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Jesse Drucker
title: Nursing Homes With Safety Problems Deploy Trump-Connected Lobbyists
description: Nursing homes, the center of the pandemic, are seeking tax breaks, federal cash infusions and protection against lawsuits.
content: Some want direct government aid. Others want tax breaks. Many want protection against lawsuits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs
title: Looming Fee Increase Could Thwart Many U.S. Citizenship Applications
description: The Trump administration is planning a sharp increase in the cost of naturalization this fall. Critics say it is part of a pattern intended to discourage immigration from poor nations.
content: WASHINGTON — When Guadalupe Rubio, 41, contracted the coronavirus in July, she struggled to make the few steps to the bathroom in the mobile home that she shared with her teenage daughter in Kent, Wash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: ‘Hidden’ Trump Voters Exist. But How Much Impact Will They Have?
description: Republicans insist that millions of Americans want to vote for Trump but won’t admit it. Polling experts tell a different story.
content: MOORESVILLE, N.C. — It wasn’t the most obvious spot for a flag that people usually buy to make a big statement. But there it was, peeking out from the inside wall of a garage, the white “Trump 2020” lettering just visible from the street in this suburban Charlotte neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Fire Tornadoes Reported in Northern California Wildfire
description: The National Weather Service issued an unusual warning on Saturday about the possibility of “a fire-induced tornado.”
content: The National Weather Service said it was planning to investigate reports of a rare occurrence of fire tornadoes arising on Saturday from a 20,000-acre wildfire in Northern California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: Japan’s Been Proudly Pacifist for 75 Years. A Missile Proposal Challenges That.
description: While acquiring weapons to counter countries like North Korea and China would be unremarkable for most world powers, in Japan it is reviving a politically sensitive debate.
content: TOKYO — Shinzo Abe is facing some of the toughest challenges of his record-setting tenure as Japan’s prime minister, with persistent flare-ups of the coronavirus, an economy mired in recession, and a public fed up with his government’s handling of the crises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: President Trump’s younger brother died Saturday night.
description: President Trump’s younger brother Robert S. Trump died Saturday night at age 71. The White House did not say what the cause was, but he had been in poor health for some time.
content: President Trump’s younger brother Robert S. Trump died Saturday night at age 71. The White House did not say what the cause was, but he had been in poor health for some time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Elijah Walker
title: Coronavirus Testing, Kamala Harris, Summer Cocktails: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: A Virginia House Candidate Tries to Leverage Transgender Bias
description: Bob Good, a self-described “biblical conservative” who is the Republican nominee for a House seat in his conservative Central Virginia district, is hoping to rally clergy members with meetings this week attacking a new state law prohibiting discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity, which he characterizes as an assault on religious liberty.
content: Bob Good, a self-described “biblical conservative” who is the Republican nominee for a House seat in his conservative Central Virginia district, is hoping to rally clergy members with meetings this week attacking a new state law prohibiting discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity, which he characterizes as an assault on religious liberty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Lovecraft Country’ and ‘Paris, Texas’
description: Catch Misha Green’s horror series set in the Jim Crow North, and revisit a classic American road trip movie.
content: LOVECRAFT COUNTRY 9 p.m. on HBO. H.P. Lovecraft’s characters and stories were a profound influence on the horror genre, but his legacy and work is also marred by racism. This series, based on Matt Ruff’s novel of the same name, reframes Lovecraft’s work by focusing on Black characters and blending supernatural horror with a critique on racial injustice. Jonathan Majors stars as Atticus Freeman, a Korean War veteran who teams up with his uncle (played by Courtney B. Vance) and his friend Letitia (Jurnee Smollett) to navigate 1950s New England in search of his missing father. In an article about the series, Salamishah Tillet wrote that its showrunner, Misha Green, also references “works by literary figures like James Baldwin and Ntozake Shange to create a provocative show that is landing amid a broader national conversation about race and representation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Robert S. Trump, the President’s Younger Brother, Dies at 71
description: A loyal spokesman for the family, he shunned the spotlight and had “zero sense of entitlement.”
content: Robert S. Trump, the younger brother of President Trump, died on Saturday night in Manhattan. He was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: Scientists See Signs of Lasting Immunity to Covid-19, Even After Mild Infections
description: New research indicates that human immune system cells are storing information about the coronavirus so they can fight it off again.
content: To the immune system, not all germs are equally memorable. But our body’s cells seem to be seriously studying up on the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: Turning Grief for a Hidden Past Into a Healing Space
description: The University of Virginia in Charlottesville, designed by Thomas Jefferson, was built by enslaved people. The Memorial to Enslaved Laborers acknowledges that long-suppressed history.
content: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — “Can we forget the crack of the whip, cowhide, whipping-post, the auction-block, the hand-cuffs, the spaniels, the iron collar, the negro-trader tearing the young child from its mother’s breast as a whelp from the lioness? Have we forgotten that by these horrible cruelties, hundreds of our race have been killed? No, we have not, or ever will.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: The Los Angeles Teams Are the Best in the West, but Questions Remain
description: Can the Lakers and the Clippers meet expectations as the N.B.A. playoffs begin?
content: On the opening night of the N.B.A.’s restart at Walt Disney World, many miles from Los Angeles, the Lakers and the Clippers put on a show. In the closing seconds, the Lakers’ LeBron James followed his own miss to convert a go-ahead put-back, then forced the Clippers’ Paul George to misfire on a 3-point attempt at the buzzer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Saw a Man Standing on One of the Paths in a Densely Wooded Area’
description: Out for a walk in Riverside Park, adventures in customer service and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: South Korea’s Outbreak, Belarus Protests, Kamala Harris: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Turn those summer peaches into a pie, perfect to cap off a dinner of cold noodles, dressed simply in chile oil and soy sauce.
content: Good morning! It’s Tejal here, writing to you from Los Angeles, filling in for Sam.
source.name: The New York Times

title: White Evangelicals’ Support for Donald Trump
description: Readers react to interviews with Christians in Sioux Center, Iowa, about why they continue to stand by the president.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucy Tompkins
title: Who Is Postmaster General Louis DeJoy?
description: The official at the center of the controversy over the Postal Service is a major Trump donor with a career in logistics.
content: Postmaster General Louis DeJoy has drawn stinging criticism for the changes he has made at the United States Postal Service since assuming the position on June 15.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: On Neutral Courts, N.B.A. Bubble ‘Home’ Teams Still Have an Edge
description: In striving to manufacture a home-court advantage where none exists, the N.B.A. and W.N.B.A. are relying on a database of music, audio cues and graphics to help teams feel at home.
content: Johnny Watson keeps an eye on the scoreboard clock whenever the Miami Heat are the home team — on paper, at least.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon and Reid J. Epstein
title: It’s Convention Time: 2-Minute Speeches, No Pomp, a Forlorn Milwaukee
description: The Democratic convention starts Monday. But none of the leading participants will be in Milwaukee, the host city. Hotels there were closed and the bars of America’s most beer-loving city were eerily barren.
content: MILWAUKEE — In a year of canceled plans, with vacations, graduations and sports seasons upended by the coronavirus crisis, the stretch of downtown Milwaukee where Democrats were supposed to hold their nominating convention this week was quiet and sparsely populated — another reminder of a summer lost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: South Dakota governor turns down extra unemployment funding, saying the state doesn’t need it.
description: Gov. Kristi Noem of South Dakota, a close Trump ally, appears to be the first state lawmaker to decline federal support designed to aid unemployed workers.
content: Gov. Kristi Noem of South Dakota, a close Trump ally, appears to be the first state lawmaker to decline federal support designed to aid unemployed workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Charles Wetli, Coroner for T.W.A. Flight 800 Crash, Dies at 76
description: Families blamed him for not identifying the victims fast enough, but in the end, he “put a name on every bit of human remains recovered.”
content: Charles V. Wetli, the Long Island medical examiner who was thrust into the national spotlight when the Trans World Airlines Flight 800 exploded in 1996 and killed all 230 people on board, died on July 28 at a hospital in Manhattan. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
title: Former Deputy Mayor of Paris Accused of Sexual Abuse
description: Allegations come atop a political downfall for Christophe Girard, who resigned after criticism of his ties to a pedophile writer.
content: PARIS — When a small group of demonstrators gathered in front of City Hall last month to demand the resignation of a powerful deputy mayor, one stood out among the clutch of mostly feminist activists: Aniss Hmaïd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Maggie Haberman
title: The Trump campaign spent millions to make sure you see its ads next week.
description: The Trump campaign is launching an aggressive four-day digital advertising campaign that will take over some of the internet’s most conspicuous real estate during the three marquee days of the Democratic National Convention — a nearly all-digital event.
content: The Trump campaign is launching an aggressive four-day digital advertising campaign that will take over some of the internet’s most conspicuous real estate during the three marquee days of the Democratic National Convention — a nearly all-digital event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush, Rebecca R. Ruiz and Karen Yourish
title: Trump’s Policies Are a Boon to the Super Rich. So Where Are All the Seven-Figure Checks?
description: Only a small fraction of the president’s top donors from 2016 have given as much to his re-election effort.
content: Timothy Mellon, reclusive heir to a Pittsburgh banking fortune, was such an unknown figure among Republican operatives that they needed to Google his name when he reached out in 2018, unexpectedly, to offer his help in the midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: A New Jersey congressman is calling for an investigation into the postal crisis.
description: A Democratic congressman from New Jersey is asking the state’s attorney general to open a criminal inquiry into what he calls President Trump’s attempts to sabotage the election by undermining the United States Postal Service.
content: A Democratic congressman from New Jersey is asking the state’s attorney general to open a criminal inquiry into what he calls President Trump’s attempts to sabotage the election by undermining the United States Postal Service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Protests Grow in Thailand, Where Speaking Out Can Be Perilous
description: Demonstrators are demanding change in a country with a long history of suppressing dissent. Some protesters are even defying the taboo against criticizing the monarchy.
content: BANGKOK — They gathered at a monument celebrating Thai democracy. They raised their hands in defiance below a giant image of the king dressed in coronation regalia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and David D. Kirkpatrick
title: The Israel-U.A.E. Deal and the Beirut Blast Both Box in Iran
description: With Arab neighbors more worried about Iran than Israel, is Tehran losing the battle for influence in the region?
content: Iran’s foreign minister flew to Beirut last week to bolster Lebanon and Hezbollah, the Iranian-backed militia and political group that plays a powerful role in the government. Both the militia and the government had been caught in a ferocious public backlash over the explosion that destroyed much of the city.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘Unwanted Truths’
description: Inside President Trump’s battles with U.S. intelligence agencies
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Suhasini Raj
title: How Kamala Harris’s Family in India Helped Shape Her Values
description: The Democratic vice-presidential pick gained part of her foundation from her mother’s side of the family, which defied stereotypes in India and promoted equality for women.
content: CHENNAI, India — One of Senator Kamala Harris’s brightest childhood memories was walking down the beach hand in hand with her Indian grandfather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Trump Says He’ll Look Into a Pardon for Edward Snowden
description: The remarks seemed to be a shift for President Trump, who repeatedly called Mr. Snowden a “traitor” and “spy who should be executed” in the years before his election.
content: President Trump said on Saturday that he would consider pardoning Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor who faced criminal charges after leaking classified documents about vast government surveillance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Tribute in Light Will Shine After All, Officials Say
description: The National September 11 Memorial & Museum had said the display would have to be canceled because of the coronavirus pandemic.
content: The National September 11 Memorial & Museum’s Tribute in Light will shine this year after all, officials said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Unemployment Checks Get Chopped
description: Millions of unemployed Americans will see their unemployment checks shrink by half.
content: Happy mid-August. Hopefully, you’re reading this someplace nice and cool and vacation-like, even if taking “out-of-office” time doesn’t feel quite the same this year. Here’s what you need to know for the week ahead in business and tech news. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Black Women Are the Superheroes the World Needs
description: In different ways and to varying degrees of success, “Watchmen” and “The Old Guard” know that these characters have a much more nuanced understanding of justice.
content: A white billionaire playboy spends his evenings fighting bad guys in a cape and mask. A white alien works as a journalist but skips out to take down villains in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Scientists See Signs of Lasting Virus Immunity, Even After Mild Infections
description: School districts across the U.S. are weighing the possibility of outdoor classes. New Zealand postponed its election amid a growing outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Dr. Jay Galst, a Specialist in Eyes and Coins, Dies at 69
description: An ophthalmologist with a numismatic hobby, he combined those interests in an unusual book. He died of the novel coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: How Biden Could Learn From Conor Lamb’s Victory in Trump Country
description: Throughout his campaign, Joe Biden has repeatedly returned to the same themes and strategies that supported Mr. Lamb to a surprise victory in a district that Donald Trump carried by about 20 points in 2016.
content: MT. LEBANON, Pa. — When Joseph R. Biden Jr. came to the Pittsburgh suburbs in 2018 to stump for Conor Lamb’s long shot special election campaign, he made a pitch directly to the sort of blue-collar union workers who had abandoned the Democratic Party when Hillary Clinton was on the ballot.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Nature Delivers a Blow to a Region Already Bleeding
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 16, 2020.
content: “The short story is 2019 was the year from hell and we were glad when it was over. Now, 2020, I don’t know what you’d call it, but it’s worse than last year.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: South Korea Warns of Another Covid-19 Outbreak Tied to a Church
description: President Moon Jae-in has vowed to crack down on the Sarang ​Jeil Church for flouting preventive measures. The church happens to be his most vocal critic.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — Health officials in South Korea reported 279 new coronavirus cases on Sunday, warning of a resurgence of infections, many linked to a church that has vocally opposed President Moon Jae-in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: 2 Dead and 9 Wounded in Cincinnati Shooting, Police Say
description: It was the deadliest of four shootings late Saturday and early on Sunday. Officials said the episodes were unrelated and a motive remained unknown.
content: A shooting in Cincinnati left two people dead and nine others wounded, the deadliest of four shootings late on Saturday and early on Sunday in the city, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Andrew Higgins
title: Belarus Protests Eclipse Rally in Defense of Defiant Leader
description: Tens of thousands of people gathered in Minsk to oppose President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko’s declared election victory.
content: MINSK, Belarus — Minutes after President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus vowed to stand firm against protesters he reviled as “rats,” “trash” and “bandits,” antigovernment demonstrators staged their biggest protest yet on Sunday to oppose a fraud-tainted presidential election a week earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Your Questions About Coronavirus Testing, Answered
description: America needs a national testing plan. In the absence of that, here’s what local governments, institutions and individuals need to know.
content: Six months into the global coronavirus pandemic, Americans trying to navigate daily life remain trapped between a clear ideal — the country needs to test as many people as possible for the virus, as regularly as possible, for as long as possible — and the reality that there are nowhere near enough tests in the United States to do that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: They’re Teens Biking Across a Turbulent Country. The Lessons Keep Coming.
description: The romance of the open road is well established: meeting strangers, self-enlightenment, getting lost and breaking down. Would these ideals hold up in the cruel summer of 2020?
content: The timing was terrible for a trip like this.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Cardinals Return With a New Appreciation for a Fragile Season
description: “My hope is people realize it can happen to anybody,” John Mozeliak, the team’s president of baseball operations, said of the virus outbreak that halted the team’s schedule for two weeks.
content: For more than two weeks, the baseball season went on without the St. Louis Cardinals. The club’s outbreak of 18 coronavirus cases — including 10 players — caused 15 postponements in a row. While the Cardinals waited, their rivals, the Chicago Cubs, seemed to win every day. There was no sense in looking at the standings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: A Virginia House Candidate Campaigns by Attacking ‘a Man Dressed as a Woman’
description: As Bob Good, an opponent of same-sex marriage, tries to rally Republicans with attacks on transgender rights, Democrats see an opening in the G.O.P.-held district.
content: Bob Good, a self-described “biblical conservative” who is the Republican nominee for a House seat in his conservative Central Virginia district, is hoping to rally clergy members with meetings this week attacking a new state law prohibiting discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity, which he characterizes as an assault on religious liberty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: Rolling Blackouts in California Have Power Experts Stumped
description: Managers of the electric system argue that a lack of power prompted the decision to enact blackouts, though demand this weekend fell short of the state’s peak years.
content: As temperatures began to rise in California on Friday and again on Saturday, the manager of much of the state’s electric grid called on utilities to cut power to hundreds of thousands of customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Gordon
title: Secret Machines Are Back. So Much Has Changed.
description: The New York City band known for explosive live shows went on hiatus in 2010 and lost a member to lymphoma in 2013. A new album finds them in a new rock landscape.
content: In the fall of 2004, an amateur music blogger named David Bowie logged onto his website to rave about the debut by an up-and-coming band called Arcade Fire. “Nothing else (and yes, I’ve heard the new U2) comes close,” he wrote, before adding a caveat: “Well, maybe ‘Secret Machines’ and their CD ‘Now Here Is Nowhere.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Bruenig
title: A Saint’s Sins
description: In California, protesters have toppled statues of Junipero Serra, whose missions brutalized Native Americans. How should we think of him now?
content: Last week, a few hours after publishing an essay about American Catholics’ reaction to the Black Lives Matter movement, I received a flood of ill tidings via email. My correspondents’ anger was unrelated to the subject of my article, but was instead inflamed by a mention of Junipero Serra, a canonized Franciscan friar who founded Spanish missions throughout California in the  18th century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Trump plans to taunt Biden near his childhood home hours before the D.N.C.
description: President Trump will travel to the battleground state of Pennsylvania on Thursday to deliver remarks attacking Joseph R. Biden Jr. just a few miles from the former vice president’s childhood home, a few hours before Mr. Biden is scheduled to take the stage at the Democratic National Convention.
content: President Trump will travel to the battleground state of Pennsylvania on Thursday to deliver remarks attacking Joseph R. Biden Jr. just a few miles from the former vice president’s childhood home, a few hours before Mr. Biden is scheduled to take the stage at the Democratic National Convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Rapid Testing Is the New Velvet Rope
description: Determined to proceed with parties and events this summer, hosts are adding screenings at the door. But such measures are hardly a guarantee of safety, medical experts warn.
content: Dr. Asma Rashid, who runs a members-only medical concierge service in the Hamptons, has received some of the most sought-after party invitations this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Can Los Angeles Schools Test 700,000 Students and 75,000 Employees? That’s the Plan
description: Classes will start remotely. But the nation’s second-largest school district has perhaps the most ambitious plan to test students and employees for the coronavirus.
content: Amid public alarm over the inadequacy of coronavirus testing across the nation, Los Angeles schools on Monday will begin a sweeping program to test hundreds of thousands of students and teachers as the nation’s second-largest school district goes back to school — online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: You May Not Know This Pandemic Winner, but Your Tween Probably Does
description: Millions of children have flocked to the online gaming site Roblox since March. That’s helping game developers, some as young as 16, make a lot of money.
content: When her middle school closed in March, Garvey Mortley stopped going to lacrosse practice and playing drums in the school band. With so much time at home, she leaned into another interest: Roblox, an online gaming site and app with Lego-like characters and millions of virtual worlds to explore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raúl Vilchis
title: These Uber Drivers Are Stressed. Archery Soothes Them.
description: Many Bhutanese immigrants who drive for ride-sharing services opted to live off their savings during coronavirus-related lockdowns in New York City. As they begin to return to work, their country’s national pastime has been a comfort.
content: Tshelthrim Dorji, a 36-year-old from Bhutan, had been used to waking up every day at 5 a.m. to start his 12-hour-shift as an Uber driver in New York City. He stopped going out during the prolonged pandemic-related lockdown, and as he slowly returned to work as the city reopened this summer he found his already taxing job increasingly stressful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Along the Ocean
description: Alan Massengill and Andrea Carla Michaels take us on a much-needed vacation.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Now this is a puzzle I can use!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Demonstrators plan a second protest at the postmaster general’s home.
description: Protesters in Washington called for the resignation of the postmaster general over the weekend, saying changes under his purview had undercut the Postal Service and threatened Americans’ ability to vote.
content: Protesters in Washington called for the resignation of the postmaster general over the weekend, saying changes under his purview had undercut the Postal Service and threatened Americans’ ability to vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Dickerson
title: A Private Security Company Is Detaining Migrant Children at Hotels
description: Under emergency coronavirus orders, the Trump administration is using hotels across the country to hold migrant children and families before expelling them.
content: The Trump administration has been using major hotel chains to detain children and families taken into custody at the border, creating a largely unregulated shadow system of detention and swift expulsions without the safeguards that are intended to protect the most vulnerable migrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: Protesters and Police Clash in Chicago as Virus Spreads
description: Police officers pepper sprayed demonstrators in Chicago on Saturday, where city leaders are facing both escalating unrest and a rising number of coronavirus cases.
content: Police officers pepper sprayed demonstrators in Chicago on Saturday, where city leaders are facing both escalating unrest and a rising number of coronavirus cases.
source.name: The New York Times
